required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Changes in DAMPs According to Duration of CPB
clinical_study.official_title: Observation of Changes in DAMPs (Damage Associated Molecular Patterns) According to Duration of Cardiopulmonary Bypass (CPB) in Cardiac Surgery

brief_summary.textblock: DAMPs (damage associated molecular patterns) are endogenous molecules that are expressed by cell stress or cell damage and play an important role in tissue (or host) defense and repair by activating the innate immune system. This is not the case with infections or injuries. Briefly, it starts when the immune system is activated by a receptor that recognizes a damage pattern, and it is a generic term for continuous responses by endogenous molecules expressed in this process. Recently, immuno-cancer drugs for cancer treatment by applying this immune response are also emerging. In cardiac surgery using cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB), there are more deleterious effects and adverse effects caused by using CPB than the surgery itself. There are several studies that have revealed the association of DAMPs and the degree of complications by approaching them from the point of view of tissue damage caused by the use of CPB. Therefore, we intend to investigate the relationship in more detail through quantitative evaluation of DAMPs before and after CPB application and time after application, and to seek ways to attenuate the degree of DAMPs according to CPB application in the future.

detailed_description.textblock:
After standard anesthesia monitoring of the patient who is admitted to the operating room for cardiac surgery, the anesthesiologist performed arterial cannulation on the radial artery with small amount of local anesthetic (2% lidocaine 1ml) because unstable hemodynamics can be expected during anesthesia induction. At this time, the blood is aspirated to remove air from the conduit after cannulation, ans small amount of blood (1-2ml) is collected and placed in a EDTA (Ethylene Diamine Tetra acetic Acid di potassium) blood test bottle (Pre-ANE).
Anesthesia is performed by administering an intravenous anesthetic (propofol1-2mg/kg) and a short-acting opioid analgesic, remifentanil (0.01-0.1mcg/kg/min). After that, anesthesia is maintained using a neuromuscular blocker and an inhalation anesthetic (sevoflurane). The anesthesia method is performed in the same way according to the "cardiac anesthesia protocol" of the Department of Anesthesiology and Pain Medicine, Pusan National University, Yangsan.
After anesthesia, the activated clotting time (ACT) is measured to determine the patient's basal clotting status before cardiopulmonary bypass is used. At this time, about 3 ml of arterial blood sample is required, and additional 1-2 ml of blood is collected and stored in an EDTA Bottle (Pre-CPB). After catheterization of artery and vein, when CPB is applied, ABGA (Arterial blood gas analysis) is performed every 30 minutes to monitor the patient's condition. At this time, the required blood volume is about 1ml, and additional 1-2ml of blood is collected and stored in EDTA, and they are labeled with CPB-30min, CPB-60min, CPB-90min, etc. When surgical correction is completed, CPB weaning is performed, and ACT and ABGA are performed once more between CPB weaning and the end of anesthesia. At this time, an additional 1-2 ml of arterial blood is collected and stored in an EDTA Bottle (Post-CPB). When a patient admitted the intensive care unit after surgery, additional 1-2ml of blood is collected and stored in the EDTA bottle (Post-OP) the next day after surgery.
The blood collected by the above method is processed by centrifugation and low temperature processing. After that, DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) and PMN (Polymorphonuclear) neutrophils are isolated from plasma using QIAmp DNA mini kit (QIAGEN, Germantown MD), and RNA (ribonucleic acid) purification for getting cDNA (complementary DNA). Quantitative real time polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) is used to investigate quantitative changes in DAMPs over time through mtDNA (mitochondrial DNA) and IL (interlukin)-6 gene expression.

primary_outcome.measure: degree of regulation of mt DNA level, and IL-6 gene expression
primary_outcome.time_frame: the day after surgery, up to 48hours
primary_outcome.description: blood sampling before anesthesia, before CPB application, 30 minutes after CPB application, after CPB weaning, the day after surgery

primary_outcome.measure: NETs (neutrophil extracellular traps) analysis in PMN neutrophils
primary_outcome.time_frame: the day after surgery, up to 48hours
primary_outcome.description: blood sampling before anesthesia, before CPB application, 30 minutes after CPB application, after CPB weaning, the day after surgery

secondary_outcome.description: By evaluating clinical recovery through the presence or absence of postoperative complications, the relationship between the degree of DAMPs and the patient's clinical prognosis was investigated.

intervention.description: There was no intervention because this reasearch is observational study.

biospec_descr.textblock: The blood collected is processed by centrifugation and low temperature processing. After that, DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) and PMN (Polymorphonuclear) neutrophils are isolated from plasma using QIAmp DNA mini kit (QIAGEN, Germantown MD), and RNA (ribonucleic acid) purification for getting cDNA (complementary DNA). Quantitative real time polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) is used to investigate quantitative changes in DAMPs over time through mtDNA (mitochondrial DNA) and IL (interlukin)-6 gene expression.

study_pop.textblock: Patients undergoing cardiac surgery using cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adult patients over 20 years of age
- Patients undergoing cardiac surgery using cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB)
Exclusion Criteria:
- pregnant women and minors
- the patients who required mechanical life support as followings due to unstable vital signs after CPB weaning, ECMO (ExtreCorporeal Membrane Oxygenation) IABP (Intraaortic ballon pumping) such as continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT)
